68099.meaning_1: Basket of Discipline; five books of the Vinaya
68099.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the cited passage the term refers to the five books of the Vinaya Piṭaka, i.e., the disciplinary corpus of the Buddhist canon.
68099.example_1: rājagahe viharati veḷuvane. atha kho tiṃsamattā pāveyyakā [pāṭheyyakā (katthaci) vinayapiṭake mahāvagge kathinakkhandhakepi] bhikkhū sabbe āraññikā sabbe piṇḍapātikā sabbe paṃsukūlikā sabbe tecīvarikā sabbe sasaṃyojanā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. atha kho bhagavato etadahosi, ime kho tiṃsamattā pāveyyakā bhikkhū sabbe āraññikā sabbe piṇḍapātikā sabbe paṃsukūlikā sabbe tecīvarikā sabbe sasaṃyojanā.

51994.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the quoted passage, mahāvagga 01 denotes the first book of the Mahāvagga, the section of the Vinaya Piṭaka currently being referenced.
51994.example_1: rājagahe viharati veḷuvane. atha kho tiṃsamattā pāveyyakā [pāṭheyyakā (katthaci) vinayapiṭake mahāvagge kathinakkhandhakepi] bhikkhū sabbe āraññikā sabbe piṇḍapātikā sabbe paṃsukūlikā sabbe tecīvarikā sabbe sasaṃyojanā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. atha kho bhagavato etadahosi, ime kho tiṃsamattā pāveyyakā bhikkhū sabbe āraññikā sabbe piṇḍapātikā sabbe paṃsukūlikā sabbe tecīvarikā sabbe sasaṃyojanā.

19882.meaning_1: chapter on the kathina ceremony; Vinaya section describing the kathina robe ceremony
19882.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In SN15.13 the term refers to the Vinaya chapter outlining the kathina robe ceremony and its related duties.
19882.example_1: rājagahe viharati veḷuvane. atha kho tiṃsamattā pāveyyakā [pāṭheyyakā (katthaci) vinayapiṭake mahāvagge kathinakkhandhakepi] bhikkhū sabbe āraññikā sabbe piṇḍapātikā sabbe paṃsukūlikā sabbe tecīvarikā sabbe sasaṃyojanā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. atha kho bhagavato etadahosi, ime kho tiṃsamattā pāveyyakā bhikkhū sabbe āraññikā sabbe piṇḍapātikā sabbe paṃsukūlikā sabbe tecīvarikā sabbe sasaṃyojanā.

61255.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the passage the term modifies "te" (they), indicating that even those who have only three robes and live in the wilderness remain "with fetters", i.e., still bound by mental defilements.
61255.sutta_1: atha kho tiṃsamattā pāveyyakā bhikkhū sabbe āraññikā sabbe piṇḍapātikā sabbe paṃsukūlikā sabbe tecīvarikā sabbe sasaṃyojanā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
61255.example_1: Then thirty mendicants from Pāvā went to the Buddha. All of them lived in the wilderness, ate only almsfood, wore rag robes, and owned just three robes; yet they all still had fetters. They bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.

25370.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the passage the term intensifies the imagery, portraying the speaker as literally “born as a cow,” highlighting the severity of the act.
25370.sutta_1: dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, gunnaṃ sataṃ gobhūtānaṃ sīsacchinnānaṃ lohitaṃ passannaṃ paggharitaṃ, na tveva catūsu mahāsamuddesu udakaṃ.
25370.example_1: For a long time you’ve been cows, and the flow of blood you’ve shed when your head was chopped off as a cow is more than the water in the four oceans.

52061.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In SN15.13 the term refers to a buffalo, listed among various beings.
52061.example_1: dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, gunnaṃ sataṃ gobhūtānaṃ sīsacchinnānaṃ lohitaṃ passannaṃ paggharitaṃ, na tveva catūsu mahāsamuddesu udakaṃ. dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, mahiṃsānaṃ [mahisānaṃ] sataṃ mahiṃsabhūtānaṃ sīsacchinnānaṃ lohitaṃ passannaṃ paggharitaṃ  … dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, urabbhānaṃ sataṃ urabbhabhūtānaṃ … ajānaṃ sataṃ ajabhūtānaṃ… migānaṃ sataṃ migabhūtānaṃ… kukkuṭānaṃ sataṃ kukkuṭabhūtānaṃ… sūkarānaṃ sataṃ sūkarabhūtānaṃ… dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, corā gāmaghātāti gahetvā sīsacchinnānaṃ lohitaṃ passannaṃ paggharitaṃ. dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, corā pāripanthikāti gahetvā sīsacchinnānaṃ lohitaṃ passannaṃ paggharitaṃ.

52071.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the passage the term denotes having been a buffalo for a long time, i.e., living in the form of a buffalo.
52071.sutta_1: dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, mahiṃsānaṃ sataṃ mahiṃsabhūtānaṃ sīsacchinnānaṃ lohitaṃ passannaṃ paggharitaṃ …pe…
52071.example_1: For a long time you’ve been buffalo …

17004.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the cited passage (sn 15.13) urabbhabhūta describes sheep that have been born as rams.
17004.sutta_1: dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, urabbhānaṃ sataṃ urabbhabhūtānaṃ …pe…

1145.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In sn15.13 the term denotes a being that has been reborn as a goat, emphasizing the transformative sense of the compound in the context of animal rebirth.

22119.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the cited context (sn15.13:3.8) “kukkuṭānaṃ sataṃ kukkuṭabhūtānaṃ …” the term refers to chickens that have been born as chickens, i.e., chickens in the sense of their natural birth as chickens.

64676.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the cited passage it qualifies pigs, indicating beings that have become pigs.

45746.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the passage it refers to an adulterer, used metaphorically to compare the spilled blood to ocean waters.
45746.sutta_1: dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, corā pāradārikāti gahetvā sīsacchinnānaṃ lohitaṃ passannaṃ paggharitaṃ, na tveva catūsu mahāsamuddesu udakaṃ.
45746.example_1: or adultery. And the flow of blood you’ve shed when your head was chopped off as a bandit is more than the water in the four oceans.

52252.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In SN15.14 the term denotes the sutta titled "Mātusutta", a discourse concerning a mother.

35794.meaning_1: not one's mother before; not previously one's mother
35794.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the quoted passage the word denotes a being that has not earlier been one's mother, emphasizing the rarity of a rebirth without that relation.
35794.sutta_1: na so, bhikkhave, satto sulabharūpo yo namātābhūtapubbo iminā dīghena addhunā.
35794.example_1: It’s not easy to find a sentient being who in all this long time has not previously been your mother.

46121.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In SN 15.15 pitusuttaṃ is a neuter compound meaning “discourse on fathers”, used as a title of a sutta.

35695.meaning_1: not one's father before; not previously one's father
35695.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
Used in the passage to denote a sentient being that has never previously been the speaker's father, emphasizing the rarity of such a being.
35695.sutta_1: na so, bhikkhave, satto sulabharūpo yo napitābhūtapubbo …pe…
35695.example_1: It’s not easy to find a sentient being who in all this long time has not previously been your father. …

49707.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In SN 15.16 this is the named sutta of the Anamataggi collection, literally a discourse on bhātu.

49154.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
The term bhaginisutta denotes the “Sister Sutta” (SN 15.17), a neuter compound formed from bhaginī “sister” and sutta “discourse”, referring to the discourse on the exhaustion of craving addressed to a bhikkhunī.

35764.meaning_1: not one's sister before; not previously one's sister
35764.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
The compound literally means “not‑sister‑before‑having‑been‑a‑being”, used in the clause “na so … nabhaginibhūtapubbo …” to express “not previously one’s sister”.
35764.sutta_1: “na so, bhikkhave, satto sulabharūpo yo nabhaginibhūtapubbo …pe…
35764.example_1: “It’s not easy to find a sentient being who in all this long time has not previously been your sister. …

46654.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In SN 15.18 the term refers to the discourse concerning sons within the Amata Saṃyutta

35697.meaning_1: not one's son before; not previously one's son
35697.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the quoted passage it qualifies a being who has never been one's son in any past existence.
35697.sutta_1: “na so, bhikkhave, satto sulabharūpo yo naputtabhūtapubbo …pe…
35697.example_1: “It’s not easy to find a sentient being who in all this long time has not previously been your son. …

35168.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In SN 15.19 the term dhītusutta denotes a sutta concerning endurance, literally “endurance sutta.”

35161.meaning_1: one's daughter before; previously one's daughter
35161.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In sn15.19.1.4 the term refers to a being who was once the speaker's daughter, highlighting the endless cycle of rebirth.
35161.sutta_1: na so, bhikkhave, satto sulabharūpo yo na dhītābhūtapubbo iminā dīghena addhunā.
35161.example_1: It’s not easy to find a sentient being who in all this long time has not previously been your daughter.

70380.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In SN 15.20 the term denotes a specific sutta dealing with the wild fruit, used to illustrate the teaching about untouched natural outcomes.

45265.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
The term refers to the former name of Vepulla mountain literally eastern bamboo formed by the compound pācīna eastern and vaṃsa bamboo
45265.sutta_1: bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, imassa vepullassa pabbatassa ‘pācīnavaṃso’tveva samaññā udapādi.
45265.example_1: Once upon a time, mendicants, this Mount Vepulla was known as Pācīnavaṁsa.

30876.meaning_1: name of the people previously living on Vepulla mountain
30876.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
Refers to the ancient tribe called the Tivaras, who inhabited Vepulla mountain before the Buddhist era.
30876.sutta_1: tena kho pana, bhikkhave, samayena manussānaṃ ‘tivarā’tveva samaññā udapādi.
30876.example_1: And at that time people were known as Tivaras.

65555.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the cited context the term refers to the former name of Vepulla mountain, literally small crooked, indicating its earlier, lesser-known form.
65555.sutta_1: bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, imassa vepullassa pabbatassa ‘vaṅkako’tveva samaññā udapādi.
65555.example_1: Once upon a time this Mount Vepulla was known as Vaṅkaka.

55455.meaning_1: name of the people previously living on Vepulla mountain
55455.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the passage rohitassā designates the tribe inhabiting Vepulla mountain, literally “the people of Vepulla”.
55455.sutta_1: rohitassā, bhikkhave, manussā vaṅkakaṃ pabbataṃ tīhena ārohanti, tīhena orohanti.
55455.example_1: It took them three days to climb Mount Vepulla, and three days to descend.

64094.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the contextual sentence supassa denotes the former name of Vepulla mountain, literally translating to “good slope.”
64094.sutta_1: bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, imassa vepullassa pabbatassa ‘supasso’tveva samaññā udapādi.
64094.example_1: Once upon a time this Mount Vepulla was known as Supassa.

64186.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the quoted passage it denotes the former name of the Vepulla mountain, used poetically as a place‑name.
64186.example_1: bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, imassa vepullassa pabbatassa supassotveva [suphassotveva] samaññā udapādi. tena kho pana, bhikkhave, samayena manussānaṃ suppiyātveva [appiyātveva] samaññā udapādi.

64185.meaning_1: name of the people previously living on Vepulla mountain
64185.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
Refers to the Suppiya tribe mentioned in the Saṃyutta Nikāya passage, denoting the people who once inhabited Vepulla mountain.
64185.sutta_1: tena kho pana, bhikkhave, samayena manussānaṃ ‘suppiyā’tveva samaññā udapādi.
64185.example_1: And at that time people were known as Suppiyas.

7115.meaning_1: name of the people previously living on Vepulla mountain
7115.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the cited passage "appiyātveva" refers to the former inhabitants of Vepulla mountain, i.e., the people called "Appiyā".
7115.example_1: bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, imassa vepullassa pabbatassa supassotveva [suphassotveva] samaññā udapādi. tena kho pana, bhikkhave, samayena manussānaṃ suppiyātveva [appiyātveva] samaññā udapādi. suppiyānaṃ, bhikkhave, manussānaṃ vīsativassasahassāni āyuppamāṇaṃ ahosi.

14601.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
The term “utu” denotes “season” and, in related forms, “fertile period”; the example sentence about Mount Vepulla does not employ this word.
14601.sutta_1: etarahi kho pana, bhikkhave, imassa vepullassa pabbatassa ‘vepullo’tveva samaññā udapādi.
14601.example_1: These days this Mount Vepulla is known as Vepulla.

58291.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
Refers to the Sutta on contentment in the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN 16.1).

13460.meaning_1: contentment with any kind of healthcare and medicinal ingredients whatsoever
13460.family_compound: itara gilāna paccaya bhisaja parikkhāra santuṭṭhi
13460.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the passage Kassapa declares his complete satisfaction with all medical requisites, using this compound to stress contentment with any healthcare and medicinal ingredients.
13460.sutta_1: santuṭṭhāyaṃ, bhikkhave, kassapo itarītarena gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārena, itarītaragilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārasantuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī; na ca gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārahetu anesanaṃ appatirūpaṃ āpajjati; aladdhā ca gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ na paritassati; laddhā ca gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ agadhito amucchito anajjhāpanno ādīnavadassāvī nissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati.
13460.example_1: Kassapa is content with any kind of medicines and supplies for the sick …

5591.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
Refers to the Anottappi Sutta, a discourse in the Kassapa Saṃyutta (SN 16.2).

3940.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the quoted passage it qualifies the lack of keenness and prudence required for awakening, describing a state of heedlessness that precludes spiritual attainment.
3940.sutta_1: “vuccati hidaṃ, āvuso kassapa, anātāpī anottappī abhabbo sambodhāya abhabbo nibbānāya abhabbo anuttarassa yogakkhemassa adhigamāya;
3940.example_1: “Reverend Kassapa, it’s said that without being keen and prudent you can’t achieve awakening, extinguishment, and the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

7071.meaning_1: not being abandoned; not being given up
7071.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the contextual sentence it conveys “not being abandoned,” i.e., refraining from allowing unskillful qualities to remain.
7071.sutta_1: “idhāvuso, bhikkhu ‘anuppannā me pāpakā akusalā dhammā uppajjamānā anatthāya saṃvatteyyun’ti na ātappaṃ karoti, ‘uppannā me pāpakā akusalā dhammā appahīyamānā anatthāya saṃvatteyyun’ti na ātappaṃ karoti, ‘anuppannā me kusalā dhammā nuppajjamānā anatthāya saṃvatteyyun’ti na ātappaṃ karoti, ‘uppannā me kusalā dhammā nirujjhamānā anatthāya saṃvatteyyun’ti na ātappaṃ karoti.
7071.example_1: “Reverend, take a mendicant who doesn’t foster keenness by thinking: ‘If unarisen unskillful qualities arise in me, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give up arisen unskillful qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give rise to unarisen skillful qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If arisen skillful qualities cease in me, they’ll lead to harm.’

26210.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
The Candūpa Sutta (SN 16.3) is a discourse concerning the term candūpa, addressing its specific doctrinal context.

24485.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the contextual sentence the negative form denies that the hand is held or caught, so gayhati here conveys “is held” with an instrumental object, used intransitively.
24485.sutta_1: “seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ayaṃ ākāse pāṇi na sajjati na gayhati na bajjhati;
24485.example_1: “Mendicants, this hand is not stuck or held or caught in space.

55726.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the passage “sn16.3:3.4” it qualifies “puññakāmā”, describing those who desire merit, i.e., those who wish for material advantage.
55726.example_1: ‘May those who want material things get them, and may those who want merit make merits!’

46524.meaning_1: desiring merit; wishing to do meritorious deeds
46524.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the cited passage “puññakāmā” qualifies “karonti” as “those who seek merit”, i.e., people intent on accumulating merit.
46524.example_1: ‘May those who want material things get them, and may those who want merit make merits!’

11375.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the given sentence it functions as an absolute phrase “having understood”, introducing the subsequent clause about practice.
11375.sutta_1: aho vata me dhammaṃ suṇeyyuṃ, sutvā ca pana dhammaṃ ājāneyyuṃ, ājānitvā ca pana tathattāya paṭipajjeyyun’ti.
11375.example_1: Oh! May they listen to the teaching from me. When they’ve heard it, may they understand the teaching and practice accordingly.’

35768.meaning_1: not one's brother before; not previously one's brother
35768.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
The term means not previously a brother, used in the passage about a being that has never been ones sibling.
35768.sutta_1: “na so, bhikkhave, satto sulabharūpo yo nabhātābhūtapubbo …pe…
35768.example_1: “It’s not easy to find a sentient being who in all this long time has not previously been your brother. …
